{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3352616,"name":"Jacob Fisher","username":"fisherjacobc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fisherjacobc/{size}/240838_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T22:12:09.163Z","cooked":"

Hi there, Kilroy is here!

We are trying out swerve drive relatively soon in the off season this year, and as the lead programmer, I have some big goals/ideas but a bit undecided on how to implement them all.

I have some stuff I want to hear from the FRC community on why they went one way or another, and if you have any other suggestions feel free to tell me.

Note: we will be using Falcon 500s for the swerve drive motors iirc

Key Issues:

  • Java vs. Kotlin (only applies to Java/Kotlin teams)
  • Pre-made swerve libraries/modules, completely custom, or a mix of both
  • What do you use your limelight (or other vision software/device) for?
  • PathPlanner vs. Choreo
","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T22:12:09.163Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":56,"reads":507,"readers_count":506,"score":431.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"Jacob Fisher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"339 Software Chairman"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/1","custom_user_title":"339 Software Chairman","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3352638,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T22:39:48.517Z","cooked":"

Sweet! Advice from a team that did this a few years back…

fisherjacobc:
  • Java vs. Kotlin (only applies to Java/Kotlin teams)

If you have multiple Kotlin experts who make their living writing Kotlin, and have deployed Kotlin to an FRC robot already - choose Kotlin.

In all other cases, choose Java

fisherjacobc:
  • Pre-made swerve libraries/modules, completely custom, or a mix of both

Pre-made for the first year. Learn to configure and debug. Figure out what frustrates you.

If enough frustrates you, for next year, write something custom over the summer.

fisherjacobc:
  • What do you use your limelight (or other vision software/device) for?

Defer till base swerve is working. After that, look into the wpilib pose estimators. And/or… a Photonvision (though not photonvision-specific) talk coming to a champs near you in a few weeks.

fisherjacobc:
  • PathPlanner vs. Choreo

Toss-up. I am a huge fan of Choreo for many reasons, but that’s not to the exclusion of other options.

Again, defer till the base-level stuff is working, but before you try to bite off vision.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T22:39:48.517Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":483,"readers_count":482,"score":131.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352724,"name":"Rahul Yarlagadda","username":"Knufire","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knufire/{size}/67820_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-05T01:45:45.859Z","cooked":"

The CTRE Swerve Library is fantastic. You get odometry running at 250hz with a slew of fancy features built in (time synchronization/latency compensation). It’s a bit of a black box in terms of interacting and customizing it, but if you read through the source code you can find places to hook in (custom SwerveRequests is a big one) to add additional functionality. It also comes with built-in Pathplanner support out of the gate, which can run both Pathplanner and Choreo paths. We’re using Choreo to generate the paths this year.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-05T02:21:57.126Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":381,"readers_count":380,"score":166.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"Rahul Yarlagadda","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7457 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/3","custom_user_title":"7457 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352742,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-05T02:20:02.939Z","cooked":"

I have said it before, maybe not here, if you can use the Tuner X Swerve Generator do so!! As one of the maintainers and creator of YAGSL I cannot and will not try to mimic the features they baked into it as it is pretty baked into their ecosystem. No other solution will come close to offering the optimizations they have with as little drawbacks.

With that said, please purchase a Pigeon2 and go for an ALL CTRE swerve drive if possible, however you can rely on other solutions if this is not feasible.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-05T02:20:27.828Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":355,"readers_count":354,"score":111.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":12760,"username":"Knufire","name":"Rahul Yarlagadda","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knufire/{size}/67820_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL & YASS Creator "},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/4","custom_user_title":"YAGSL & YASS Creator ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352743,"name":"UnofficialForth","username":"UnofficialForth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/unofficialforth/{size}/167902_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-05T02:21:11.518Z","cooked":"

That’s the number one reason we plan to switch to an all Kraken Drivetrain next year. It goes hard.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-05T02:21:11.518Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":334,"readers_count":333,"score":66.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"UnofficialForth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":12760,"username":"Knufire","name":"Rahul Yarlagadda","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knufire/{size}/67820_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29982,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC Team 4272 Mentor | World's FLL Emcee"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/5","custom_user_title":"FRC Team 4272 Mentor | World's FLL Emcee","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352750,"name":"Ashton A","username":"UHDbits","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/u/a5b964/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-05T02:38:16.797Z","cooked":"

We got our swerve drive running in about 10 minutes with the Tuner X Swerve Generator. It’s honestly crazy how quickly and how well it works. One thing I would say about it is that I would recommend looking through the TunerConstants file after the project is generated, because there are some settings there that you still might want to tune (mainly things like current limits).

I do agree about the customizability of the swerve generator, and I think that is the one major drawback. If you are getting started with swerve, you probably won’t mind, but it can feel annoying or frustrating at some times. We’ve personally started our custom swerve drive code based off the code from Mechanical Advantage, which is another great resource, but I personally wouldn’t go with it until you are pretty comfortable with another prebuilt library. The CTRE Swerve Generator would be the first place I would first start if I didn’t know anything about swerve.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-05T02:38:16.797Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":314,"readers_count":313,"score":77.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"Ashton A","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63823,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1165 - Lead Programmer/Driver"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/6","custom_user_title":"1165 - Lead Programmer/Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3354941,"name":"Jacob Fisher","username":"fisherjacobc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fisherjacobc/{size}/240838_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-08T13:41:01.623Z","cooked":"

Thanks for all the help & feedback everyone, we really appreciate it! We will still be looking at this in the future for any ideas, but will most likely finalize stuff within the next couple weeks.

I will post again what we are planning to do in case there are any objections/better ways to do it in case we overlooked something.

In response to the quote below, I’m pretty much the only programmer, and have been doing some Kotlin work, since I think it’s a very viable option considering the massive pros and little cons compared to Java, namely the extensibility of it.

gerthworm:

If you have multiple Kotlin experts who make their living writing Kotlin, and have deployed Kotlin to an FRC robot already - choose Kotlin.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-08T13:41:01.623Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":245,"readers_count":244,"score":64.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"Jacob Fisher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"339 Software Chairman"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/7","custom_user_title":"339 Software Chairman","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3355180,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-08T16:31:03.311Z","cooked":"

Massive con: All docs and examples are in Java, not Kotlin. And few folks in FRC know the details of both. You’re basically on your own when it comes to translating back and forth. And you will have to translate if you want help.

I won’t deny you the learning opportunity - but I won’t encourage Kotlin either.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-08T16:31:21.373Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":219,"readers_count":218,"score":43.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":56841,"username":"fisherjacobc","name":"Jacob Fisher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fisherjacobc/{size}/240838_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3355239,"name":"","username":"apple","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/b9e5f3/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-08T17:10:29.696Z","cooked":"

We used Kotlin this season, and at least personally I really enjoyed it. It’s similar enough to Java that most people familiar with Java can still get the gist by just reading through the code, and imo it wouldn’t be much harder to teach to new students either. In my experience, the vast majority of “code” issues at events aren’t actually with the code itself but more with the interaction of it with motor controllers, sensors, etc., so while CSAs helped us many times throughout the season, I don’t believe we ever really even showed them the code (and if we did, it was a few lines of business logic that barely differ between Java and Kotlin), so Java vs Kotlin did not impact us much there.

In my experience, the largest difference between Java and Kotlin for robot code are in the choices you have about how to structure your code, which usually doesn’t show up much in short code examples in docs and such, so it’s not too hard to translate them from Java to Kotlin if necessary.

As a note, I did have one issue with using Kotlin this season, which was that if you attempt to deploy code but it fails to compile, then your code will not start on the RIO. It’s not a super breaking issue, but something to keep in mind while doing e.g. a last minute deploy before a playoffs match (bit us at an offseason event). Haven’t had the time to debug and figure out if it’s an issue with GradleRIO, our build.gradle, or something else, but oddly the old code seems to still be on the RIO, and can be started manually by connecting to the RIO over ssh and running it, but it will not start on its own.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-08T17:12:14.404Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":205,"readers_count":204,"score":71.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":56841,"username":"fisherjacobc","name":"Jacob Fisher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fisherjacobc/{size}/240838_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63149,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3355315,"name":"Co-Head Mentor 3658","username":"robocodepodcast","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/robocodepodcast/{size}/195585_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-08T17:48:10.408Z","cooked":"
Ashton A:

One thing I would say about it is that I would recommend looking through the TunerConstants file after the project is generated, because there are some settings there that you still might want to tune (mainly things like current limits).

Can you speak more to this comment you made: “One thing I would say about it is that I would recommend looking through the TunerConstants file after the project is generated, because there are some settings there that you still might want to tune (mainly things like current limits).” please and thank you.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-08T17:48:10.408Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":167,"readers_count":166,"score":38.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"Co-Head Mentor 3658","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28325,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3355329,"name":"Tyson Whelan","username":"Tyson453","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/e56c9b/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-08T17:53:02.429Z","cooked":"

When using CTRE Swerve generator, a file called “TunerConstants.java” is created. This defines all of the constants that the CTRE swerve library will use. One of the main things you should check in this file is current limits as it is defaulted to 300 Amps. All they meant by their comment is to make sure you go through this file and make sure everything looks right. Look up or ask what any of the constants mean if you don’t know.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-08T17:53:02.429Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":160,"readers_count":159,"score":37.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"Tyson Whelan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":28325,"username":"robocodepodcast","name":"Co-Head Mentor 3658","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/robocodepodcast/{size}/195585_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51010,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2357 Drive Coach"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/11","custom_user_title":"2357 Drive Coach","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3355678,"name":"Jonathan J","username":"MeditativeOnion","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/meditativeonion/{size}/223004_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-08T22:08:17.931Z","cooked":"

This may be a bit biased from experience, but I would prefer Java over Kotlin simply because it’s more likely that new members know Java, and using a less popular language runs the risk of having a point in your future where there are not enough programmers fluent in Kotlin to sustain the department.

For limelight, my team has been pretty unambitious so far, using it mainly for aiming shots and, very recently, for pose estimation during auton.

Our swerve code is custom, but libraries are also a good choice. WPILib has enough support for swerve calculations for custom code to be feasible in the first year (we did it that way), but it does mean that you usually have to do more work when dealing with problems that come up.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-08T22:08:17.931Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":155,"readers_count":154,"score":31.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"Jonathan J","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65762,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/13","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3355820,"name":"","username":"rachitkakkar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rachitkakkar/{size}/268638_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T00:39:09.120Z","cooked":"

Our team decided to use Java for a number of reasons, including that it is the most popular language in the FRC community, our past codebase uses Java, and new members are more likely to know Java (from AP CS).

Our most important decision was to roll out our own custom library, PurpleLib, to package and make it easy to use swerve utilities across our various robot projects (including our offseason swerve and main season robot). These utilities included robot rotation PID, traction control, and wheel odometry wrapped in a pretty extensive class supporting MAXSwerve modules. Perhaps the most significant advantage we sought to gain was wrapping a ton of common hardware (motor controllers, swerve modules, NavX2, and more) to implement logging with AdvantageKit by default. This was done to gain all the benefits of logging almost every sensor value (especially for debugging and simulation) in a way that is transparent to the end-programmer (interfacing with these hardware objects with the familiar APIs they would expect and requiring no additional effort). You can read more about PurpleLib at the repo linked above, or this Chief Delphi post. It primarily supports REV hardware, but we are working on adding support to CTRE hardware.

We used a MinisForum UM690S running PhotonVision to localize the robot using AprilTags, allowing automatic aiming based on distance from the speaker and automatic “search-and-destroy” for game pieces using the included object and color detection feature of PhotonVision. Also, localization increased the reliability of our autos when paired with the NavX. Check out our robot code if you are curious.

I haven’t used Choreo, but we have used PathPlanner relatively successfully, although we had to rely on our “search-and-destroy” feature in order to more reliably intake the far notes. Our more advanced functionality included ending our intake command based on whether a limit switch was triggered (rather than relying on a timeout) as well as our auto-aim and “search-and-destroy”/auto-intake commands.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-09T01:03:49.382Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":145,"readers_count":144,"score":84.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/introducing-purplelib-a-custom-library-for-robot-code/450203","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Introducing PurpleLib: A Custom Library for Robot Code","clicks":6},{"url":"https://github.com/lasarobotics/PH2024","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - lasarobotics/PH2024: 2024 Purple Haze FRC","clicks":4},{"url":"https://github.com/lasarobotics/PurpleLib","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - lasarobotics/PurpleLib: Custom library for 418 Purple Haze","clicks":2},{"url":"https://photonvision.org","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"PhotonVision","clicks":0},{"url":"https://github.com/Mechanical-Advantage/AdvantageKit","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - Mechanical-Advantage/AdvantageKit: Monorepo for robot framework and tools","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60259,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Former Embedded Software Lead for LASA Robotics ('23-'25)"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/14","custom_user_title":"Former Embedded Software Lead for LASA Robotics ('23-'25)","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3356256,"name":"Ashton A","username":"UHDbits","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/u/a5b964/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T14:10:55.875Z","cooked":"

although we had to rely on our “search-and-destroy” feature in order to more reliably intake the far notes. Our more advanced functionality included ending our intake command based on whether a limit switch was triggered (rather than relying on a timeout) as well as our auto-aim and “search-and-destroy”/auto-intake commands.

This is pretty much exactly what we do with PathPlanner, and it specifically turned us away from Choreo because of it. I’m not sure exactly how this works with PathplannerLib, but as far as I understand, Choreo paths do not support automatic path replanning. This means you can’t really go out of the way to automatically align to/intake a note, or aim towards the speaker (although I think Choreo has translation points where you can control the rotation in the code, so it might be possible to auto aim towards the speaker), unless you want to make a on-the-fly path which drives to where the Choreo path starts, which I think would add a lot of slowdown to the auto.

I personally think PathPlanner is the better way to go for a beginner. Choreo really depends on the accuracy of some of the values that you put in, and the UI in general is also a bit more clunky to use. PathPlanner has some annoying UI issues too, but those are things you eventually just figure out how to work around.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-09T14:12:30.361Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":112,"readers_count":111,"score":32.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"Ashton A","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":60259,"username":"rachitkakkar","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rachitkakkar/{size}/268638_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63823,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1165 - Lead Programmer/Driver"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/15","custom_user_title":"1165 - Lead Programmer/Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3356265,"name":"viggy96","username":"viggy96","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/viggy96/{size}/252784_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T14:15:18.567Z","cooked":"

We didn’t use path replanning for this, and we had many issues with PathPlanner ending path execution, before the robot could reach the desired endpoint. We are considering other options like Choreo to use next year.

For the “search-and-destroy”, we simply used PhotonVision colored shape detection, and drove the robot straight at the target, steering the bot based on the yaw angle reported by PhotonVision.

Sorry if I’m confused, but doesn’t driving the robot straight backwards and turning it force the path to be modified? If you aren’t consistently stopping in the same place everytime, you need to replan the path to get to where you are going (or, that’s how I understand it). As far as I know PathPlanner does that automatically.

We also just drive straight backwards and steer towards the note using the yaw from a Limelight 2+ running PhotonVision, and we haven’t had any issues with the path accuracy, but I can agree that we have had issues with PathPlanner ending paths early. We specifically have encountered issues where PathPlanner doesn’t finish rotating before the path is finished, causing us to shoot to the left or the right of the speaker. It doesn’t happen everytime, but we have had it happen sometimes at our competition.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-09T14:19:20.068Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":16,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":98,"readers_count":97,"score":24.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"Ashton A","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24613,"username":"viggy96","name":"viggy96","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/viggy96/{size}/252784_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63823,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1165 - Lead Programmer/Driver"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/17","custom_user_title":"1165 - Lead Programmer/Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3356283,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T14:30:28.990Z","cooked":"

This is no longer the case. The default “slip” (stator) current limit is 150 amps now from the generator last time I checked. We have used that limit all season with a input current limit of 80 for .75 s and 40 steady state without a problem.

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-09T14:30:28.990Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":89,"readers_count":88,"score":17.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":51010,"username":"Tyson453","name":"Tyson Whelan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/e56c9b/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/18","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3356290,"name":"viggy96","username":"viggy96","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/viggy96/{size}/252784_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T14:36:57.262Z","cooked":"

Our path doesn’t go all the way to the note. The path in PathPlanner ends about halfway up the stage. Then we start our search and destroy command, that is completely independent of PathPlannerLib.

Then, once the note is in our indexer, we execute the final path, which does require initial replanning, to drive back from where we currently are, up closer to the speaker to shoot.

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-09T14:39:30.014Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":17,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":87,"readers_count":86,"score":22.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"viggy96","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":63823,"username":"UHDbits","name":"Ashton A","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/u/a5b964/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24613,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/19","custom_user_title":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3356308,"name":"Ashton A","username":"UHDbits","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/u/a5b964/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T14:49:59.066Z","cooked":"

Okay, this is what I was thinking. Sorry if I made it sound like the path was replanned as it was running, but I meant that the path needs to be replanned at the very start. As far as I know, Choreo paths do not support path replanning at all, because of the nature of how they are generated and how precise they are.

","post_number":20,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2024-04-09T14:49:59.066Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":19,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":82,"readers_count":81,"score":16.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":461328,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-polls","display_username":"Ashton A","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24613,"username":"viggy96","name":"viggy96","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/viggy96/{size}/252784_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63823,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1165 - Lead Programmer/Driver"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-polls/461328/20","custom_user_title":"1165 - Lead Programmer/Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3356341,"name":"Ishaan Masilamony","username":"StarkOdinson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/starkodinson/{size}/191062_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T15:10:45.748Z","cooked":"

I would just use the AdvantageKit swerve template (basic or advanced depending on what you need). It’s basically plug and play, you just need to add in a few tweaks to suit your bot. Additionally, using Akit also makes life a whole lot easier when doing debugging later on in the process.

As for vision, we use it for field localization, which is then used in auto and teleop for shooting.

I would do Pathplanner, but with Choreo trajectories.
